awd_abstract_narration:
Extremal combinatorics is a central area of combinatorics and has experienced an impressive growth in recent few decades.  It deals with the problems of finding the maximum or minimum value of a function over a class of finite objects. Such problems are often related to other branches of mathematics and other fields of science, including biology, chemistry, computer science, information and coding theory. 

Classical extremal problems, such as Sperner's theorem and Turan's theorem, consider the size of a set system or graph. On the other hand, results such as Dirac's theorem on Hamilton cycles and the Hajnal-Szemeredi theorem, consider the minimum or maximum degree of a graph. The proposed research considers degree versions of several classical results in extremal set theory, including the Erdos-Ko-Rado theorem and the Kruskal-Katona theorem. An obvious difficulty towards solving these problems is that the shifting method, an important tool in extremal set theory, can not be applied. The project also considers degree versions of two well-known difficult problems in extremal (hyper)graph theory: the clique density problem and hypergraph Turan problem. Lastly, extending Dirac's theorem to hypergraphs has attracted much attention in recent years, and the PI will continue his research on this topic. The tools that the PI will apply to attack these problems include the algebraic method, probabilistic method, flag algebra method, absorbing method, and regularity method.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

During the period of support, the PI has 18 papers published or accepted and additional 3 papers under review. One half of his papers appeared on top journals in his field, including the Journals of Combinatorial Theory A, B, and Combinatorics, Probability and Computing.

The objective of Grant DMS 1700622 is studying extremal problems on graphs and hypergraphs under degree conditions. The PI and his collaborators have resolved or made progress on all proposed problems and investigated several other problems. For example, Hao Huang and the PI determined the largest minimum degree of intersecting families of k-element sets on n elements. This result implies the well-known Erdos-Ko-Rado theorem. Huang and the PI proved their result by elegant algebraic arguments, which enable them to obtain a best possible bound for n.

 

Broader Impacts

Out of these 18 papers, the PI wrote 12 papers with former or current PhD students. During the period of support, the PI gave 18 invited talks, including 11 seminars and 5 talks at the AMS sectional meetings. He also gave a mini course on Extremal Combinatorics to over fifty students and faculty members at the Central China Normal University in May 2018.

The Atlanta Lecture Series in Combinatorics and Graph Theory have been held in three major research universities (Emory University, Georgia Tech, and Georgia State University) in Atlanta since 2010. These mini-conferences have attracted students and researchers in metro-Atlanta area, including many from non-PhD-granting institutes. The PI has been assisting in the organization and logistics of the conferences, including inviting speakers and organizing conference events.

In 2017 the PI supervised two minority undergraduate students, Isabella Nang (female) and David George (African American) on their research projects. In 2017 the PI invited the US Olympiad head coach Po-Shen Loh to give a public lecture at GSU. The lecture was co-sponsored by Georgia Council of Teachers of Mathematics and attracted over one hundred middle and high school students and their parents.
